tweetContentProcessed: Kyona and Kenneth Zak found a covenant in their deed with a rider stating that discriminatory clauses were not enforceable That didnt seem like enough for us now its redacted and rejected Kenneth Zak said On their updated deed the covenant is visible but crossed out
tweetContent: Kyona and Kenneth Zak found a covenant in their deed with a rider stating that discriminatory clauses were not enforceable. “That didn’t seem like enough for us, now it’s redacted and rejected,” Kenneth Zak said. On their updated deed, the covenant is visible but crossed out.
description: An image of a deed with a hand pointing to it, and the text: The language remains in countless property records and homeowners may not even know that their deed includes a covenant.

description: An image of a recycling symbol and text that reads: What can you actually recycle? Items marked "1" and "2" are widely recyclable in U.S. curbside recycling programs. "5" is also increasingly recyclable. Other numbers indicate that no, those items probably aren't recyclable. Soft plastics like shopping bags or sandwich packaging are almost always accepted in curbside programs.
